nodes.text: Incumbency power (deviation from perfect democracy) and institutional design determine dynamic selection and persistence of good or bad governments; democratic institutions increase adaptability to shocks while incumbency advantage can cause persistence of incompetent governments

Model: discrete-time dynamic game where a government is any feasible coalition G, government competence maps G to a scalar competence value, individuals get utility from competence and rents from membership, and changes require votes from society plus consent threshold l of current members

Equilibrium concept: (Markov) political equilibrium defined by a transition function phi mapping current government to next government; phi characterized recursively (equation 6) and coincides with Markov perfect equilibria of an explicit proposal-voting extensive form when discounting high and shocks infrequent

Assumptions: (i) stage utilities increase with competence and individuals strictly prefer being in government (rents) so conflicts of interest exist; (ii) winning coalitions require m votes and consent of l members; (iii) generic distinct competences and optional competence decomposition by individual abilities
Result (nonstochastic): Perfect democracy (l = 0) uniquely yields inevitable emergence of the most competent government from any initial government (phi(G)=best)

Result (nonstochastic): Any deviation from perfect democracy (l >= 1) admits at least one additional stable government; even the least competent government can be stable and persist forever under small incumbency advantage

Claim (comparative regimes, nonstochastic): Beyond perfect democracy there is no general ranking among imperfect democracies and dictatorships; identity of initial government strongly influences long-run equilibrium competence

Claim (stochastic environments): With stochastic shocks to competences, greater degree of democracy (lower l) increases institutional flexibility and raises the probability that high-competence (including the best) governments come to power; perfect democracy immediately implements the best post-shock government

Evidence / Theorem: Existence and uniqueness of acyclic political equilibrium mapping phi for high discount factors; phi constructed recursively (Theorem 1) and stable governments are fixed points D = {G : phi(G)=G}

Method detail: explicit extensive-form proposal and sequential voting game with 'sheltered' vs 'unstable' periods, nomination protocol and primaries; Markov perfect equilibria of this game coincide with the political equilibrium mapping phi under assumptions (Appendix B)

Evidence / Theorem (stochastic): When shocks are infrequent, stochastic political equilibria follow phi for each competence configuration; characterization parallels nonstochastic case (Theorem 3 and 6) and implies that shocks can destabilize and lead to transitions determined by new phi

Illustrative results and mechanisms: small incumbency consent (even l=1) can make improvements unstable and thus cause incumbents to block reforms that would ultimately exclude them; examples (n=6,k=3,l=1) show worst government can persist forever

Comparative implications and refinements: (i) imperfect democracies can sometimes outperform less democratic regimes in nonstochastic settings (nonmonotonicity); (ii) with shocks more democracy dominates (higher probability of best government); (iii) 'royalty-like' regimes (irreplaceable members) can outperform 'junta-like' dictatorships under shocks when ability distribution is sufficiently convex

Limitation and caveats: results rely on assumptions of common knowledge of competences, high discounting, rare shocks for tractability; frequent shocks or asymmetric information (unobserved abilities) complicate equilibrium structure and are open extensions

Policy-relevant claim: democratic institutions may deliver a key advantage through adaptability to environmental change rather than necessarily better performance in any single static environment; design of consent rules l crucially shapes persistence and flexibility
